fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A presheaf on a category C is a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\to Set. The presheaf category \hat {C} is the functor category Set^{C^\text {op}} of presheaves on C.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A simplicial set is a presheaf on the abstract simplex. The category of simplicial sets sSet is the category of presheaves on the abstract simplex.

Let P be a presheaf and S a sieve on x. Regarding S as a subfunctor of C(-, x), a matching family of P for S is just a natural transformation S\to P. Explicitly, a matching family assigns, to each y\xrightarrow {f} x in S, an element p_f\in P. This data must be compatible with restriction via P, in that p_f|_g = p_{fg} for all z\xrightarrow {g} y.
A presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set on a site is a sheaf if, for all objects x and covering families S, each natural transformation S\xrightarrow {\alpha } P lifts uniquely to C(-, x):

fr:title.text: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every presheaf category is complete and cocomplete, with limits and colimits computed as in Set.
Limits and colimits are computed pointwise and Set is complete and cocomplete.

fr:title.text: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set be a presheaf. Then the subobject poset of P is a Heyting algebra.
For any category C, the category of presheaves \hat {C} is cartesian closed.

Products are computed pointwise, hence inherited from Set. By the Yoneda lemma, for c\in C an exponential Q^P, if it exists, should satisfy Q^P c \cong \hat {C}(yc, Q^P)\cong \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). Taking this to define Q^P, we now show the desired adjunction.

Fixing some P and Q suffices to construct the evaluation natural transformation Q^P\times P\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}} Q (itself the Q-component of a natural transformation (-)^P\times P\to P) which induces an isomorphism on adjoint hom-sets. At c\in C, the component \operatorname {ev}_c is given a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\phi } Q and an element p\in Pc; we define \operatorname {ev}_c(\phi , p) = \phi _c(1_c, p).

Now, it remains to show that there is a bijection \hat {C}(R, Q^P)\xrightarrow {-\times P} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q^P\times P)\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}_*} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q). That is, given a natural transformation R\times P\xrightarrow {\alpha } Q, we must show that there is a unique natural transformation R\xrightarrow {\beta } Q^P mapping to \alpha . At c\in C, this is a set-function Rc\xrightarrow {\beta _c} Q^Pc, where the latter is the set \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). As such, for each element r\in Rc, we must define a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\beta _c(r)} Q.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set be a presheaf, y\xrightarrow {f} x\in C a map, and p\in Px an element. Then the restriction of p along f, or the pullback of p along f, is p|_f = Pf(p). The restriction maps of P are just the induced set-functions Pf for each morphism f.

fr:title.text: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since every presheaf is a colimit of representables, hence a colimit of objects in the image of the Yoneda embedding, and the functor \hat {F} must preserve colimits, there is (up to isomorphism) only one candidate fomula: given a presheaf P, we must have \begin {aligned} \hat {F}P &= \hat {F}(\operatorname *{colim}(\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C})) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C}\xrightarrow {\hat {F}} E) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P) \xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xrightarrow {F} E). \end {aligned} By functoriality of colimits, this is well-defined.

By the proof of the density formula, we recognize this as the colimit formula for the Kan extension of F along y. (Indeed, since the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful, this Kan extension is necessarily an isomorphism, so that this extension necessarily makes the triangle commute.)

Let \hat {C} be a presheaf category. Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {\Omega } Set be the sieve functor, which sends an object x to the set of sieves on x, and a map y\xrightarrow {f}x to its action on sieves by restriction: (\Omega f)(S) = \{g: fg\in S\}. Let *\xhookrightarrow {\top } \Omega (where * is the constant functor at the singleton) identify for each x\in C the maximal sieve. Then \top is a subobject classifier in \hat {C}.

Let Q\hookrightarrow P be a subobject in \hat {C}. We need to define the classifying natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\chi _Q}\Omega ; we work in components. At an object x\in C, this map must send an element p\in Px to a sieve on x; we choose the sieve (\chi _Q)_x(p) = \{z\xrightarrow {f} x\in C: p|_f \in Qz\}. In other words, this sieve consists of those maps which restrict p to an element of Q.

Next, to show that it is a pullback, it suffices to show that it is a pullback at each x\in C, and by the construction of limits in Set, it suffices to show that (\chi _Q)_x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. The backwards direction is already done; conversely, if it is the maximal sieve, then we obtain the result by observing that 1_x\in (\chi _Q)_x(p) and applying the definition of \chi _Q.

Finally, to show uniqueness, suppose that we have another natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\theta } \Omega . By the above argument, for the square to be a pullback, we must have that \theta _x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. Now further, given z\xrightarrow {f} x and applying the same fact at z, we must have that p|_f\in Qz if and only if \theta _z(p|_f) is the maximal sieve. By naturality of \theta at a map f, we have that \theta _z(p|_f) = \Omega f(\theta _x(p)), which by definition of \Omega is the maximal sieve if and only if f\in \theta _x(p). As a consequence, if the square is a pullback, we must have that f\in \theta _x(p) if and only if p|_f\in Qz, yielding exactly the definition of \chi _Q above.

fr:title.text: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements \text {el}(F) has a initial object. Dually, a presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements has a terminal object.

First let c\in C represent F, so that there is a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F. Then the pair (c, \alpha _c(1_c)) is initial in \text {el}(F). Indeed, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), the bijection \alpha _d determines a unique element f\in C(c, d) so that Ff(\alpha _c(1_c)) = y; this exactly expresses initiality.

Conversely, let (c, x) be initial in \text {el}(F). By the Yoneda lemma, the element x\in Fc determines a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\Phi (x)} F; we need to show this is an isomorphism. Initiality of (c, x) asserts that, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), there is a unique map c\xrightarrow {f_y} d such that Ff_y(x) = y. Now in the proof of the Yoneda lemma, \Phi (x) was constructed so that F(\Phi (x)_d)(f) = Ff(x), so the assignment (d, y)\mapsto f_y inverts \Phi (x)_d.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and let c\in C be an object. By the Yoneda lemma, a choice of x\in Fc corresponds to a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\alpha _x} F. Such a choice expresses a universal property of c if \alpha _x is an isomorphism, and hence a representation. In this case, x is called a universal element.
The analogous dual definition applies to presheaves.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf and A\in C an object. Let y be the Yoneda embedding and \hat {C} be the presheaf category. Then \hat {C}(yA, F)\cong FA, and this bijection is natural in F and A. Furthermore, the image of a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha } F under this bijection is \alpha _A(1_A).
Dually, let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and A\in C an object. Then \operatorname {Hom}(C(A, -), F)\cong FA.
We prove the contravariant (presheaf) case. The proof is in three parts: the bijection, and the two naturality claims.
The Yoneda embedding C\xrightarrow {y}\hat {C} of C into its presheaf category is the functor with action
In other words, it is a curried version of the hom functor.

Let c be an object in a category C. The contravariant hom-functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {C(-, c)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(x, c) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f^* by pre-composition:
This functor is also called the presheaf represented by c, and is written yc, y^c or h^c, the former two in reference to the Yoneda embedding.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
A contravariant functor between categories C and D is a functor F: C^\text {op}\to D.
Let C and D be categories. The functor category D^C has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as identities, the identity natural transformations.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
